NAME OF THE TRACTATE
Derek ’Ereẓ is the title of two tractates: Rabbah (the large) and Zuṭa (the small). They consist mainly of moral and ethical teachings. Contrary to what we might expect, they are not larger and shorter divisions of the same treatise, but independent works with but little in common. Consequently, the terms Rabbah and Zuṭa cannot have been parts of the original titles.

Many passages in Derek ’Ereẓ are to be found, with slight variations, in the Babylonian and Jerusalem Talmuds. For other sayings, however, no source is found in Rabbinic literature. This would indicate that these collections of Baraithoth belong mainly to the period of the Tannaïm. Subsequently, additions were made to the original text, since the tractates include dicta from much later authorities.

Among the early authorities the treatises were known as Hilkoth (the laws of) D.E., Masseketh (tractate) D.E., Middoth (rules of) D.E., Pirḳë (chapters of) D.E., Mishnath (the Mishnah of) D.E., or simply Derek ’Ereẓ. In the current editions printed in the Talmud, the tractates Rabbah and Zuṭa each consists of eleven chapters, several in the former being somewhat longer than in the latter. The text for the present translation follows in the main that of the Wilna-Romm edition; but note has been taken of the most important variants found in MSS. and other printed editions, some of which have been adopted in the translation, with explanations in the notes. Constant reference has also been made to the variant readings and emendations of the Wilna Gaon (GRA), as well as other commentaries printed in the same edition of the Talmud.

The term Derek ’Ereẓ signifies ‘good manners, propriety, correct behaviour, refinement, etiquette’. These have always been regarded as most important in Jewish life. Already in the Bible many instances are recorded of good manners and correct conduct. To quote but a few: the filial love and respect shown by Shem and Japheth in covering the nakedness of their father, Noah; Abraham waiving his right as the elder and allowing his nephew, Lot, to choose the land he desired; Abraham’s hospitality to the angels; Rebekah’s kindness to Eliezer and his camels; the gallantry displayed by Moses in helping Jethro’s daughters, which may serve as an instance of respect towards women; the command to rise before the aged and honour the elder; the duty to assist the poor with interestfree loans; the precept of humanitarianism and charitableness towards an enemy and his animals; the laws guaranteeing civil, moral and religious rights to the stranger and proselyte; and the exhortation to avoid personal and moral pollution by keeping the camp holy.
<small>ANALYSIS OF THE TRACTATE</small>

The first two chapters were also known under the title Tractate ‘Arayoth (prohibited marriages). According to the Wilna Gaon, they do not belong here but to Kallah. Several MSS., indeed, begin DER at the third chapter, and in them the whole work is entitled Pereḳ Ben ‘Azzai from the opening words. The author of the Maḥzor Viṭri (who was a disciple of Rashi) makes this tractate begin with the fourth chapter. Both these variants are noted in the current editions printed in the Talmud.

In Coronel’s edition of Ḥamishshah Ḳunṭrasim (1864) we find many passages in Kallah which are more suitable in Derek ’Ereẓ. Hence both these tractates may have been compiled about the same time, some passages becoming misplaced. In the view of Coronel there was also a Gemara attached to this tractate (as with Kallah Rabbathi) which antedated the redaction of the Talmud. But from a study of the language and style of the last-named it would seem to belong to a later period.

The first chapter was probably a separate work. It deals with marriages which are forbidden on account of consanguinity and concludes with some ethical maxims on the subject of marriage. The second chapter, too, may have been a separate collection, because its subject-matter is entirely different from the first. It contains reflections on twelve classes of persons who are to be condemned and twelve who are to be commended, with Biblical texts appropriate to each. Then comes a list of sins which bring about the eclipse of the heavenly luminaries and other misfortunes, and the chapter ends with some mystic remarks on God and Israel and the three hundred and ninety heavens.

The following chapters, much of whose contents is also found in ARN, consist of ethical, moral and social teachings generally expressed in pithy sentences, arranged in the style of the Pirḳë Aboth, except that they are anonymous. They conclude with a list of occupations which are to be avoided, followed by a collection of liturgical prayers for special occasions.
<small>DATE OF COMPOSITION AND THE TEXT</small>

As already stated, the nucleus of the tractate was composed in the Tannaitic period, to which were added teachings of the early ’Amoraïm. Not only is the meaning of some passages so obscure that we must assume that obvious errors must have crept in, but some passages are clearly out of place. The current text is often corrupt. There are MSS. and editions of both Rabbah and Zuṭa which contain numerous variations both in text and order. Rabbi Dr. M. Higger, in his edition (New York, 1935), lists the most important of these differences.

The following reasons may be suggested as accounting for these variations. We must recognize a distinction between literature in the strict sense, i.e. a work composed in accordance with literary rules and conventions, and a compilation which was intended for oral transmission and only later reduced to writing. Each has its own characteristics. Oral tradition tends to develop certain peculiarities to aid the memory; e.g. the grouping together in convenient summaries of ten, seven, five or three; the juxtaposition of certain laws or sayings which have a common catchword.

With literary composition of the strict kind, on the other hand, the logical connection is the rule to be followed. From the Rabbinic dictum, ‘The words transmitted orally thou art not at liberty to recite from writing’ (Giṭ. 60b, Sonc. ed., p. 284), some scholars have inferred that no records of the oral Torah existed before the fifth century <small>C.E.</small>, the great mass of rulings and opinions which developed through the centuries being retained in the Schools entirely without the aid of writing. But this view is based on a misinterpretation of the passage. It only means that the oral Torah may not be committed to writing to be used as textbooks in the Schools.

The objection to committing the oral Torah to writing arose from the fear that it might become confused with, and be given the same authority as, the text of the Torah. But the teachers must have possessed much material in written form, and no doubt prepared their lectures from collections of this kind, treating them, however, for reference only and not as textbooks. They were not allowed to read their lecture from MS., to avoid creating the impression that the discourse carried the same authority as the Scriptures. Even Rabbi Judah the Prince, who, as many maintain, wrote down the Mishnah, as did R. ‘Aḳiba and R. Meir before him in their codifications, intended it to be a work of reference and not a textbook.

Teaching continued to be oral and from memory until the sixth century, when new conditions demanded a change in method. The material was by that time too vast to be retained by memory only. The existence of the Academies was threatened by persecution, and it was resolved to reduce to definitive form all that had hitherto been preserved orally.

If errors could creep into halakic (legal) material, as we find, though great care must have been taken against this happening, how much more so with a subject like Derek ’Ereẓ, especially if it was committed to writing only after a lapse of time! Whereas with halakah notes of legal decisions might have been sufficient to aid one’s memory, with Derek ’Ereẓ the need was felt to have fuller notes, perhaps for the guidance of one’s family circle. In such a collection errors inevitably crept into the text, either from lapse of memory or through copyists’ mistakes.

They who smite in secret, openly blaspheme, treat the public with contempt and causers of strife are destined to be like Ḳorah and his assembly, concerning whom Scripture declares, And the earth closed upon them, and they perished from among the assembly.5(5) Num. 16, 33.

Concerning them who hoard fruit,6(6) To raise the price. raise the prices, make the ephah small and the shekel great7(7) Cf. Amos 8, 5. and lend money on usury, Scripture declares, The Lord hath sworn by the pride of Jacob: Surely I will never forget any of their works.8(8) ibid. 7. Cf. B.B. 90b (Sonc. ed., pp. 372f.).

The following do not bequeath anything to their children, and if they do bequeath to their children they do not cause their children’s children to inherit: the dice-gambler, the breeder of small cattle,9(9) Sheep, goats, etc. Breeders of small cattle were generally frowned upon because they permitted them to graze in other people’s fields. one who transacts with money derived from the Sabbatical year,10(10) Trading with the produce of that year is prohibited. one whose money is derived from [transactions] with overseas countries11(11) Danger attended the transport of freights at sea and one might suffer loss. and a kohen or Levite who borrowed on their portions.12(12) i.e. terumah and ma‘aser respectively. If a kohen or Levite borrowed money from a lay-Israelite on the understanding that the loan would be repaid from the tithe due to them, they thereby offer an inducement to that man to give the tithe only to them. Such action is considered unfair and undignified.

Concerning flatterers, liars and workers of iniquity,13(13) So GRA. V repeats from §1, ‘Sadducees, informers, flatterers’ and adds ‘profaners of God’s Name’. Instead of the Scriptural passages which are cited GRA substitutes Job 13, 16, and Ps. 101, 7, in agreement with Soṭah 42a (Sonc. ed., p. 206). Scripture declares, The wicked shall return to the nether-world,14(14) Ps. 9, 18. and it further states, That which is crooked cannot be made straight.15(15) Eccl. 1, 15.

Concerning them who moan like a dove,16(16) Cf. Isa. 38, 14, LIX, 11. Here and in what follows the mannerisms of proud men are alluded to. who make motions with their hands [when talking],17(17) [So Jastrow, s.v. num I.] click their heels and walk on tip-toe, Scripture declares, Let not the foot of pride overtake me, and let not the hand of the wicked drive me away.18(18) Ps. 36, 12.

Concerning haughty men, purveyors of slander, them who use lewd language and them who are wise in their own eyes19(19) Self-opinionated persons. Scripture declares, For, behold, the day cometh, it burneth as a furnace.20(20) Mal. 3, 19.

Concerning him who takes a wife for his infant son, who marries his daughter to an old man21(21) Since she does not willingly accept him, she may be led to adultery. and who does a favour to one without notifying him22(22) GRA reads ‘to a heathen’ to agree with Sanh. 76b (Sonc. ed., p. 517), the favour referring to the return of a lost article. Scripture declares, The Lord will not be willing to pardon him.23(23) Deut. 29, 19.

Concerning tax-collectors, confiscators, extortioners and collectors of customs, Scripture declares, Thy riches, and thy wares, thy merchandise, thy mariners, and thy pilots, thy calkers, and the exchangers of thy merchandise, and all thy men of war, that are in thee, with all thy company which is in the midst of thee, shall fall into the heart of the seas in the day of thy ruin.24(24) Ezek. 27, 27.

Concerning him who deceives his partner, who does not return a lost object to its owner, who lends money to his fellow with the object of foreclosing his house or his field, who indulges in perversion with his wife, and who lays wanton charges against his wife in order to divorce her, Scripture declares, I the Lord search the heart, I try the reins.25(25) Jer. 17, 10. [Büchler, Studies in Sin and Atonement, p. 401, n. 4, remarks: ‘These are things done in private or planned in the secret of the heart, against which the teachers fought by moral pressure’.]

Concerning them who suffer insults but do not insult, who hear themselves reviled and do not answer back, who perform [religious precepts] from love26(26) Of God and not the expectation of reward. and rejoice in their chastisements,27(27) Because imposed by God either to test their faith or to punish them in this world for their sins, rewarding their virtues in the hereafter. Scripture declares, But they that love Him be as the sun when he goeth forth in his might.28(28) Judg. 5, 31.

Concerning them who have a humble opinion of themselves, who are low in their own estimation, who subdue their [evil] inclination and who are humble of spirit, Scripture declares, Thus saith the Lord, the Redeemer of Israel, his Holy One, to him who is despised of men, to him who is abhorred of nations, to a servant of rulers: Kings shall see and arise, princes, and they shall prostrate themselves.29(29) Isa. 49, 7.

Concerning trustworthy men, them who keep a secret, who return a pledge and who restore a lost object [to its owner] Scripture declares, Mine eyes are upon the faithful of the land, that they may dwell with me.30(30) Ps. 101, 6.

Concerning him who loves his wife as himself and honours her more than himself,31(31) By providing her with adornments (Rashi). Cf. Sanh. 76b (Sonc. ed., p. 517), Yeb. 62b (Sonc. ed., p. 419). who leads his children in the right path and marries his son just before he attains puberty, before he comes within the power of sin, Scripture declares, And thou shalt know that thy tent is in peace; and thou shalt visit thy habitation, and shalt not sin.32(32) So lit. E.V. and shalt miss nothing. Thou shalt know also that thy seed shall be great, and thine offspring as the grass of the earth.33(33) Job 5, 24f.

Concerning him who loves his fellow-men, who displays friendliness towards his relatives, who marries his sister’s daughter34(34) One has greater affection for a sister than for a brother; hence his affection for his wife, his sister’s daughter, will be the greater. and lends a peruṭah to a poor man in the time of his need, Scripture declares, Then shalt thou call, and the Lord shall answer.35(35) Isa. 58, 9.

Concerning them who confess their sins in earnestness,36(36) So H. GRA reads: ‘who lead [their community] with righteousness’. repent wholeheartedly, receive penitents and teach them to return from their sinful ways, Scripture declares, Then shall thy light break forth as the morning.37(37) ibid. 8.

Concerning them who judge in righteousness, who reprove with sincerity, who perform [their daily tasks] in a state of [ritual] cleanliness and who are pure of heart, Scripture, declares, Surely God is good to Israel, even to such as are pure in heart.38(38) Ps. 73, 1.

Concerning them who sigh, grieve and look forward to [national] salvation and mourn for Jerusalem, Scripture declares, To appoint unto them that mourn in Zion, to give unto them a garland for ashes.39(39) Isa. 61, 3.

Concerning them who are merciful, who feed the hungry, give drink to the thirsty, clothe the naked and distribute alms Scripture declares, Say ye of the righteous, that it shall be well with him.40(40) ibid. III, 10. [Ẓaddiḳ, ‘righteous’, is here connected with ẓedaḳah which is used in Rabbinic Heb. for ‘charity’.]

Concerning the poor, the bashful, the lowly of spirit, those who are gentle to the young41(41) There are various renderings of the word tishḥoreth. Cf. Aboth, Sonc. ed., p. 35, n. 6. and trustworthy men Scripture declares, Thou shalt also decree a thing, and it shall be established unto thee, and light shall shine upon thy ways.42(42) Job 22, 28.

Concerning them who toil in [propagating] the Torah, who study the Torah for its own sake, who are constantly in search of performing meritorious deeds and who wait for [the opening of the doors of] temples [of prayer and learning] Scripture declares, Happy is the man that hearkeneth to me, watching daily at my gates, waiting at the posts of my doors.43(43) Prov. 8, 34.

Concerning them who pursue righteousness, who seek peace for their people, who grieve with the community and stand by them in the hour of their distress Scripture declares, The Lord is good, a stronghold in the day of trouble; and He knoweth them that take refuge in Him.44(44) Nahum 1, 7.

On account of four things is the sun in eclipse;45(45) lit. ‘smitten’. on account of an ’Ab Beth Din who died and was not fittingly mourned;46(46) With an appropriate memorial address. on account of a betrothed maiden who cried out aloud in the city and there was none to rescue her;47(47) Cf. Deut. 22, 24. on account of sodomy; and on account of two brothers whose blood was shed at the same time.

On account of four things are the luminaries48(48) The moon and stars. in eclipse: on account of those who forge documents; on account of those who give false evidence; on account of those who breed small cattle;49(49) Cf. above, §6. and on account of those who cut down good trees.50(50) Even though they are their own property; cf. Suk. 29a (Sonc. ed., p. 131).

51(51) [On this and the next paragraphs, cf. Büchler, op. cit., p. 90, n. 1.] On account of four things the wealth of householders is confiscated by the government: on account of those who retain in their possession bills which have been paid;52(52) In the hope of claiming them again. on account of those who lend money on usury; on account of those who had the power to protest [against wrongdoing] and failed to do so; and on account of those who publicly donate specified sums for charity and do not give them.53(53) Suk. loc. cit.

On account of four things is the property of householders appropriated by the State treasury:54(54) For the fiscus. on account of those who withhold the hired labourer’s wages; on account of those who delay payment of the labourer’s wages; on account of those who remove the yoke from off their own neck and place it on their fellow-men;55(55) The reference is to those who evade payment of taxes so that the burden falls more heavily on others. and [the sin of] arrogance is equal to them all.

R. Dosethai b. Judah said: One should always56(56) In Ber. 7b (Sonc. ed., p. 36) the text reads ‘it is permitted to’. contend with the wicked, as it is stated, They that forsake the law praise the wicked; but such as keep the law contend with them.57(57) Prov. 28, 4. Should somebody whisper to you, ‘[But is it not written,] Contend not with evildoers, neither be thou envious against them that work unrighteousness?’58(58) Ps. 37, 1. E.V. fret not thyself because of evildoers. answer him, ‘Only he whose conscience pricks him59(59) lit. ‘whose heart knocks him’. So GRA in agreement with Ber. loc. cit. speaks thus. Contend not with evildoers means, to be like them; be not envious against them that work unrighteousness means, to emulate them’.

In the heavenly abode60(60) In the World to Come; cf. Ber. 17a (Sonc. ed., p. 102). there is no sitting, eating, drinking, sleeping, procreation of children, enmity, hatred, rivalry, envy, obduracy, weariness or hindrance.

The same was said by David, king of Israel; for it is stated, He made darkness His hiding-place.61(61) Ps. 18, 12. With reference to whom did David say this verse? He only said it by way of praising the Holy One, blessed be He, Who is Yah ruling in the heights of the universe; He is One and His name is One, and He dwells in three hundred and ninety firmaments.62(62) The Heb. for ‘heaven’, שמים, has the numerical value 390. Upon each firmament His Name and attributes are inscribed; in each are Ministering Angels, Seraphim, Ophannim,63(63) lit. ‘wheels’, cf. Ezek. 1, 15ff. Cherubim, celestial spheres64(64) The spheres of the zodiac. and the throne of glory. Do not wonder too much at this statement; because a king of flesh and blood has a number of residences, some for warm weather and some for cold weather; how much more so [can this be said] of the King, the Life of the universe, since everything belongs to Him! When Israel perform the will of the All-present, [56b] He dwells in Araboth the seventh [heaven]65(65) The seventh heaven is the abode of righteousness, justice and peace; cf. Ḥag. 12a (Sonc. ed., pp. 71f.). and He does not disinterest Himself in anything [in the world]; as it is stated, From between the two cherubim; and He spoke unto him.66(66) Num. 7, 89. But when He is wroth, He ascends and dwells in the upper heavens, and though people cry aloud and weep, their voices are not heard, even though they decree a fast, wallow in ashes, clothe themselves in sackcloth and shed tears.

Ben ‘Azzai said: Whoever sets the following four things [constantly] before his eyes and upon his heart will never commit a sin: Whence he came, whither he goes, Who is his Judge and what he is destined to become. Whence he came? From a place of darkness. Whither he goes? To a place of thick darkness. [Another reading:] Whence he came? From a place of uncleanness. Whither he goes? To cause others to be unclean.1(1) The human body, when dead, causes ritual defilement. [Another reading:] Whence he came? From a fetid drop and from a place which no person is able to behold.2(2) The womb. Whither he goes? To the nether-world to be judged in Gehinnom3(3) So GRA. V and H read ‘and Abaddon’, a name for the nether-world. and burnt in fire. And Who is his Judge? He must realize that his Judge is not of flesh and blood but the Lord of all works, blessed be He, with Whom there is no injustice, forgetfulness, respect of persons or taking of bribes. What is he destined to become? A worm and maggot; as it is stated, How much less man, that is a worm! and the son of man, that is a maggot!4(4) Job 25, 6.

R. Simeon said: A man is [full of] worms during his life and [full of] maggots when dead. He is full of worms during life—i.e. vermin, and full of maggots when dead—i.e. what swarms when he is dead.5(5) Another possible interpretation is that he feels the bite of maggots even when he is dead; cf. Shab. 13b (Sonc. ed., p. 54), ‘Worms are as painful to the dead as a needle in the flesh of the living’.

R. Eleazar b. Jacob said: Man is comely and praiseworthy but emits an ugly expression from his mouth. To what can this be compared? To a large salon in the middle of which a tannary pipe was fixed. So is man: if now when he discharges excrement from his bowels he prides himself over other creatures, should he emit from his bowels foliatum,6(6) An ointment or oil prepared from the leaves of spikenard. balsam or any other kind of aromatic spice, how much more would he pride himself over other creatures!7(7) Following the text of GRA. Cf. above, p. 543.

Shortly before R. Eleazar b. Azariah died, his disciples went in to visit him.8(8) Cf. Ber. 28b (Sonc. ed., p. 173). They sat in front of him and said, ‘Master, teach us the ways of life’.9(9) So GRA. V has ‘only one subject’. He said to them, ‘My sons, what can I teach you? Go and let each of you be solicitous for the honour of his colleague; and when you stand up to pray, know before Whom you stand and pray; for on that account you will [be worthy to] enter into the life of the World to Come’.

Five things we learnt from R. Eliezer at the time of his death, and we had greater joy over what we then learnt than over what he taught us during his life.10(10) They rejoiced because his teaching was accepted. The laws which he taught in his lifetime were rejected since he had been excommunicated. After his death the ban was lifted. They are: a ball, a shoe-last, an amulet, tefillin and a cushion can become unclean, and [if unclean] may be immersed just as they are.11(11) For the explanation of this teaching, cf. ARN XIX, p. 108, n. 6. Instead of ‘as they are’ another reading is bemashehu, i.e. in a small quantity of water and not the full measure of forty se’ah. Go and pay due regard to them, because they are important ordinances which were told to Moses on Mount Sinai.

You should always be pleasant on entering and leaving [a house]. Spend less time on business and occupy yourself with [the study of] the Torah. It once happened that R. Simeon b. Eleazar1(1) Others read ‘R. Eleazar b. R. Simeon’. But the story here related is more befitting the character of his son, R. Simeon. Cf. B.M. 85a (Sonc. ed., p. 487). was coming from Migdal Eder2(2) In the extreme south of Judah. from the house of his teacher and was riding leisurely on his ass by the seaside.3(3) In Ta‘an. 20a (Sonc. ed., p. 100) ‘riverside’. A certain man4(4) According to some it was Elijah who wanted to teach him a lesson. chanced to meet him, who was exceedingly ugly. He said to him, ‘Raḳa,5(5) lit. ‘empty one’, good-for-nothing. how ugly are the children of Abraham our father!’6(6) Some versions read: ‘Are all your fellow-citizens as ugly as you?’ Cf. above, p. 295. The other replied, ‘What can I do for you? Speak to the Craftsman Who made me’. R. Simeon b. Eleazar immediately dismounted from the ass, prostrated himself before him7(7) R. Simeon realized that he had done wrong. and said to him, ‘I apologize to you, forgive me’. He replied to him, ‘I will not forgive you until you go to the Craftsman Who made me and say to Him, “How ugly is the vessel which You have made!” ’ R. Simeon walked behind him for three mil.8(8) V and H ‘half a mil’. When his fellow-citizens heard [of his arrival] they came out to meet him, greeting him with the words, ‘Peace be upon you, Rabbi’. The man said to them, ‘Whom are you calling Rabbi?’ They answered, ‘He who is walking behind you’. Thereupon he exclaimed, ‘If this man be a Rabbi, may there not be any more like him in Israel!’ He told them the whole story. They earnestly begged him to pardon him, and he replied, ‘I will forgive him, but only on condition that he does not act9(9) So GRA and H. V has ‘speak’. in the same manner again’. That same day R. Simeon sat and expounded in his great Academy: Be always pliable like the reed and not unyielding like the cedar. In the case of a reed, though the four winds of the world were to blow upon it, the reed bends with them, and when the winds drop, it remains standing in its place, with the result that one is able to make a pen of it to write a scroll of the Torah. But the cedar is not like that: if the east, north [or] west wind blows upon it, it cannot move it from its place; but as soon as the south wind blows upon it, it uproots it and the result is that people come and cut it up,10(10) The translation follows the corrected text of GRA. chop it and use it for building houses, and what is left is used for firewood. Therefore the Sages said: Be always pliable like the reed and not unyielding like the cedar.11(11) Cf. Ta‘an loc. cit.

How does one honour his teacher? When they are both walking along the way, he must place himself at his12(12) The teacher’s. left hand and not at his right. If three [were walking together] and a Sage or a teacher was among them, the teacher is to be in the middle, the more important of the other two on his right and the less important on his left. We find it so in connection with the three angels who came to Abraham our father, viz. Gabriel, Michael and Raphael. Gabriel came to overthrow Sodom and Gomorrah, Raphael came to heal Abraham13(13) Of the effects of his circumcision. and Michael came to announce to Sarah [that she would have a son]. Michael was in the middle, Gabriel on his right and Raphael on his left.14(14) Cf. Yoma 37a (Sonc. ed., p. 172). When Abraham our father saw the Ministering Angels, the Divine Presence appeared and stood over him. He said to them, ‘Sires, wait until I take leave of the Divine Presence, which is greater than you’, as it is stated, And he said: My lord, if now I have found favour in thy sight, pass not away, I pray thee, from thy servant.15(15) Gen. 18, 3. Abraham addressed the chief of them and consequently the word lord does not signify God. Others interpret that he spoke to God, praying Him to wait until he had attended to his guests. They therefore cite here ibid. XVII, 22, And He left off talking with him, and God went up from Abraham. When Abraham our father had taken leave of the Divine Presence, he came, bowed to them and led them beneath the tree, as it is stated, Let now a little water be fetched, and wash your feet,16(16) ibid. XVIII, 4. and afterwards [it is written], And I will fetch a morsel of bread.17(17) ibid. 5. But [when the angels came] to Lot, what did he say? And tarry all night, and wash your feet.18(18) ibid. XIX, 2. Abraham had mistaken the angels for Arabs, who worship the dust of their feet and, being anxious not to introduce idolatry in any form into his house, he asked them to wash their feet first. Lot, however, who had no such anxiety, offered them a night’s lodging before asking them to wash their feet. Others, who give the interpretation which follows in the text, maintain that Lot also was anxious that they should first wash their feet, a custom he had learnt from Abraham; but the reason that he told them to stay the night before washing was to deceive the people of Sodom. Others say: Lot spoke to them [in this manner] only as a clever device. He said [to himself], ‘If [the men of Sodom] find them with their faces, hands and feet already washed, the result will be that they will kill me, my wife and my daughters.19(19) For not reporting their arrival earlier. Let them, therefore, find them with the dust still on their feet, and they will think that they have only just arrived’.

He who walks behind his teacher may not leave him without first obtaining his permission. If they were both equal in learning, the host enters [the house] first and then the guest, but when leaving the guest goes out first and the host leaves last.20(20) The reason is not to leave the wife unprotected; cf. Ta‘an. 23b (Sonc. ed., p. 120). He who is about to leave the company of his fellow,21(21) So GRA. V and H read ‘his teacher’. whether he be greater than he or not, must say to him, ‘I am leaving’.

A person should never leave [the company of his teacher or even] his fellow unless he had previously obtained his consent. All can learn such good manners from the All-present, Who said, as it were, to Abraham, ‘I am now leaving’, as it is stated, And the Lord went His way,1(1) God notified Abraham that He was departing. as soon as He had left off speaking to Abraham; and Abraham returned unto his place.2(2) Gen. 18, 33. The translation follows the emended text of GRA. V’s reading is: ‘Who said to Abraham, “Abraham, has he any further need of Me?” He said before Him, “Lord of the Universe, no” ’.

A man should never enter his fellow’s house suddenly;3(3) Cf. Nid. 16b (Sonc. ed., p. 112). and all can learn such good manners from the All-present, Who stood at the entrance of the Garden [of Eden] and called to Adam,4(4) To announce His presence. as it is stated, And the Lord God called unto the man, and said unto him: Where art thou?5(5) Gen. 3, 9. The story is told of the four Sages, viz. Rabban Gamaliel, R. Joshua, R. Eleazar b. Azariah and R. ‘Aḳiba, who were on their way to attend a Privy Council6(6) Or, lit. ‘an interior kingdom’. which also included a certain philosopher as a member. R. Joshua said to Rabban Gamaliel, ‘Master, would you like us to call on our companion the philosopher?’7(7) To confer with him before the meeting. He replied, ‘No’. In the morning he again asked him, ‘Master, would you like us to call on our companion the philosopher?’ He replied, ‘Yes’. R. Joshua went and knocked on the door. The philosopher thought and said [to himself], ‘This can only be the manners of a Sage’. [When he knocked] a second time, [the philosopher] got up and washed his face, hands and feet. On the third knock he arose and opened the door and saw the Sages of Israel coming all together.8(8) lit. ‘some from here and some from there’. Rabban Gamaliel was in the middle, R. Joshua and R. Eleazar b. Azariah on his right and R. ‘Aḳiba on his left. The philosopher was meditating and saying [to himself], ‘How shall I greet these Sages of Israel? If I say, “Peace be upon you, Rabban Gamaliel”, I shall be guilty of derogatory conduct towards the [other] Sages. If I say, “Peace be upon you, Sages of Israel”, that would be an insult to Rabban Gamaliel’.9(9) Who had the title of Prince or Patriarch, and was President of the Great Sanhedrin in Jerusalem. As soon as he approached them, he greeted them with the words, ‘Peace be upon you, Sages of Israel, headed by Rabban Gamaliel’. (We learn [this rule of etiquette] not from [this story of] Rabban Gamaliel but from the Divine Presence, as it is stated, I saw the Lord sitting on His throne, and all the host of heaven standing by Him on His right hand and on His left.)10(10) 1 Kings 22, 19. This passage is omitted by GRA and printed in V within brackets. He inserts it in chap. IV towards the end and reads: ‘We learn this [rule] not only from the angels but from the Divine Presence’, etc.

Always let all people [who visit you] be regarded by you as robbers, but show them the same respect as to Rabban Gamaliel. The story is told of R. Joshua on whom a certain person called early in the morning. He gave him food and drink, and took him up to the loft to sleep and then removed the ladder from under him. What did that man do? He arose in the middle of the night, collected the vessels11(11) Which were stored in the loft. and wrapped them up in his cloak. As soon as he started to descend,12(12) Thinking that the ladder was still there. he fell from the loft and broke his neck. When morning came, R. Joshua rose early and found him where he had fallen. He said to him, ‘Raḳa!13(13) Cf. p. 545, n. 5. do all persons act as you have?’ He replied, ‘Master, I did not know that you had removed the ladder from under me’. He said to him, ‘Raḳa! Do you not know that already yesterday14(14) From the moment you arrived we were suspicious of you?’ Hence R. Joshua said: Always let all men be in your eyes as robbers, but show them the same respect as to Rabban Gamaliel.

If one enters a house [by invitation], whatever the host tells him he must do.1(1) Some eds. add: ‘providing it is a thing permitted to be done’. Cf. Pes. 86b (Sonc. ed., p. 456, n. 6) where the margin adds ‘except depart’. This is probably meant humorously—a guest should not outstay his welcome until he is told to go! Others read מצא for מדא ‘except a forbidden thing’, which harmonizes with the addition in our text. The story is told of R. Simeon b. Anṭipaṭros with whom many guests used to come and stay. When he pressed them to eat and drink, they vowed by the Torah that they would neither eat nor drink, but later they partook of food and drink. When the time came for them to depart he used to flagellate them. This matter came to the notice of Rabban Joḥanan b. Zakkai and the Sages who were angered by it. They said, ‘Who will go and inform us [of his action]?’ R. Joshua replied, ‘I will go and see how he conducts himself’. He went and found him at the entrance of his house and greeted him, ‘Peace be upon you, Master’. The other replied, ‘Peace be upon you, Master and Teacher’. He said, ‘I need a lodging’. The other replied, ‘Lodge here in peace’. They sat down and occupied themselves in the study of the Torah until evening. In the morning [R. Joshua] said to him, ‘Master, I want to go to the bath-house’. He replied, ‘As you wish’;2(2) Not a positive approval. whereupon R. Joshua was afraid lest he would smite him on his thighs. After he returned [from the bath-house] they ate and drank. He then said, ‘Who will accompany me [on my way back]?’ The other replied, ‘I will’. R. Joshua was then meditating and saying [to himself], ‘What can I report to the Sages who sent me [to institute inquiries]?’3(3) Since there was nothing untoward in the man’s behaviour. He then turned [to look] back. [R. Simeon] asked him, ‘Master, why did you turn to look behind you?’ He replied, ‘I have something to ask you. Why did you flagellate other guests who stayed with you and me you did not flagellate?’ He said to him, ‘Master, you are a great Sage and you have good manners. The persons who stay with me I usually press to eat, but they vow by the Torah [not to eat] and transgress [their vow]; and so have I heard from the mouth of the Sages that whoever vows by the Torah and breaks his vow has to be given forty lashes’. He said to him, ‘May Heaven bless you for what you have done. By your life and by the life of your head! Whoever behaves in this manner, give him the forty lashes on your account [57a] and [another] forty on account of the Sages who sent me’.4(4) i.e. I do not mind how much you flagellate him. R. Joshua returned and reported to the Sages what he had witnessed while he was with Simeon b. Anṭipaṭros.

A man should never be fastidious concerning his meals. It once happened that Hillel the Elder had a certain man to a meal, when a poor person came and stood at his door and said, ‘I am to marry today and have no provisions at all’. Hillel’s wife took the entire meal [which she had prepared] and gave it to him. She then kneaded fresh dough, cooked another dinner and placed it before them. He said to her, ‘My dear, why did you not bring it to us sooner?’ She told him all that had happened. He said to her, ‘My dear, I, too, did not judge you in the scale of guilt but in the scale of merit, because everything you did was only in the name of Heaven’.

We do not leave over a portion of the food in a stew-pot, but we should leave over a portion of the food in the dish.5(5) The text is emended by GRA to agree with ‘Erub. 53b (Sonc. ed., p. 373). Cf. also Midrash Lamentations 1 (Sonc. ed., p. 85). V and H insert ‘not’ in the second instead of the first clause. When food is poured from the pot into the dish, none should be left over in the pot for the servant; but when the contents of the dish are ladled into the plates, some must be left in the dish for him. It once happened that R. Joshua was the guest of a certain widow who served him with a dish of beans. He ate without leaving any. On the second occasion he also ate without leaving any. On the third occasion she over-seasoned it with salt; and as soon as R. Joshua tasted it he withdrew his hand from it and ate his bread dry. She asked, ‘Why did you withdraw your hand from the pounded beans?’ He replied, ‘I had already eaten earlier in the day’. She said to him, ‘You should then have withdrawn your hand also from the bread’. ‘Perhaps,’ she continued, ‘you left [the dish today] as compensation for the former meals!6(6) When you ate it all. But have not the Sages said: We do not leave over a portion of the food in the stew-pot but we should leave over a portion of the food in the dish!’7(7) The corrected text of GRA is reproduced in translation. The hostess subtly rebuked R. Joshua for not having left some of the food. Hence R. Joshua said, ‘No one has ever had the better of me except this woman, a little boy and a little girl’. What was the incident with the little girl? Once R. Joshua was walking in a field when he met a little girl who called out to him, ‘Why are you walking across the field?’ He replied, ‘I am walking along a [trodden] path’. ‘Robbers like yourself,’ she retorted, ‘have trodden it down.’ What was the incident with the little boy? Once R. Joshua was on a journey and came across a little boy sitting at a cross-road. He asked him, ‘My son, by which road will I be able to go to the town, by this one or by that?’ He replied, ‘Both of them are before you; but this one is long and short and that one is short and long’. [He proceeded along the short but long road.] When he approached the city’s wall, he found that it was surrounded by gardens and orchards, and turned back. Noticing the same little boy sitting where he had left him, he said, ‘My son, why did you play a trick on me? Did you not tell me that this road was short?’8(8) So GRA. ‘Master,’ he retorted, ‘you are a great Sage and this is your wisdom? Did I not tell you that it is long?’9(9) The last words are inserted by GRA. R. Joshua went and kissed him upon his head and exclaimed, ‘Happy are you, O Israel, for all of you are wise, both young and old’.

How does one dance before a bride?10(10) What does one recite or sing in praise of a bride? Beth Shammai said, ‘The bride as she is’.11(11) One should not exaggerate, and if she is obviously not beautiful one should not say that she is. Beth Hillel said, ‘Beautiful and graceful bride’.12(12) Every bride should be complimented. Beth Shammai said to Beth Hillel, ‘According to your view, if she were lame or blind one still has to call her “beautiful and graceful bride”, but the Torah has declared, Keep thee far from a false matter!’13(13) Ex. 23, 7. Beth Hillel replied to Beth Shammai, ‘If one has made a bad purchase in the market, should one praise it in his eyes or depreciate it? Surely one should praise it in his eyes’. Therefore the Sages said: The disposition of man should always be pleasant with people.

One should break off a piece of bread14(14) For the purpose of reciting the Grace before meals. only from the part that is baked to a crust and not from the soft part;15(15) i.e. a piece of the outer surface must be taken for the purpose and not the inner dough. neither should one hold in his hand a piece [of bread] as big as an egg,16(16) And eat it all at once; he should only eat a quantity as large as an olive. because one who acts in this manner is a glutton and a tippler, neither should a man drink his goblet of wine in one draught, and if he did so he is a tippler and a glutton. How many pauses should he make before drinking it up? [If he drinks it] in two draughts he shows good manners; in three he is of the arrogant. A man should not begin to eat leek or onion from the top side but from the leaves, and if he did eat it so he is a glutton and a tippler. He should not drink two goblets for reciting Grace after meals because it makes him appear like a tippler.17(17) Cf. Ber. 51b (Sonc. ed., p. 310) where the reason given is connected with ‘pairs’, alluding to the idea that even numbers are unlucky and cause a person to come under the influence of evil spirits. Our text, however, can be explained in accordance with Pes. 110b (Sonc. ed., pp. 568f.) where it states that in Palestine they are not particular about ‘pairs’; it is nevertheless forbidden for the reason given here.

When two sit at one table, the senior of them puts forth his hand first1(1) To pick his portion from the dish. On the Oriental mode of dining, cf. Lane, Manners and Customs of the Modern Egyptians, p. 148. and then the junior; if the junior puts forth [his hand first] he is a glutton.

The story is told of R. ‘Aḳiba who prepared a meal for his disciples. They2(2) The waiters. served them with two dishes, one raw and the other cooked. First they served them with raw foods. The bright [pupil] among them took hold of the stalk with one hand and with the other tried to break a piece off, and when it did not come off he withdrew his hands from it and ate his bread dry.3(3) He realized that he could only break off a piece by using much force and that would be unmannerly. The foolish [pupil], however, took hold of the stalk in one hand and bit into it with his teeth. R. ‘Aḳiba said to him, ‘Not so, my son; place your heel on it in the plate!’ After that a cooked dish was served to them, of which they ate their fill. Then [R. ‘Aḳiba] said to them, ‘My sons, I only did this to test whether you have good manners or not’.
A man should begin his mealtime at the fourth hour of the day4(4) i.e. 10 a.m., the beginning of the day being 6 a.m. and enter the bath-house only at the fourth hour of the day.5(5) Not earlier.
Hot baths in large quantities are harmful to the body and beneficial in small quantities; wine is harmful in large quantities and beneficial in small quantities.6(6) Cf. Giṭ. 70a (Sonc. ed., p. 334).
The following three things are of equal importance, viz. wisdom, fear [of God] and humility.

When entering a privy one should not face west or east7(7) So as not to expose himself towards the Holy of Holies. but only the sides.8(8) i.e. north and south, which are not in line with the Holy of Holies; cf. Ber. 61b (Sonc. ed., p. 387). He should not expose himself until he sits, and should not wipe himself with the right hand but only with the left.9(9) The Moslems have a similar practice and do not touch food with the left hand; cf. Lane, op. cit., p. 150, n. 2. It is related of R. ‘Aḳiba that he went into a privy behind R. Joshua to watch his behaviour. He noticed that he entered the privy only on the side, exposed himself10(10) In Ber. 62a (Sonc. ed., p. 388) ‘evacuated’. only after he had sat down, and wiped himself only with the left hand. What is the reason that we do not wipe with the right hand? R. Eliezer said: Because one eats with it. R. Joshua said: Because one writes11(11) So GRA. V has ‘drinks’. with it. Rabban Gamaliel said: Because one points with it to the cantillations of the Torah.12(12) [In a copy of the Heb. Bible when reading it aloud; cf. N.Y.]

A man should not rejoice when among people who weep or weep when among those who rejoice. He should not stay awake among people who sleep or sleep when among those who are awake. He should not be standing when all others are sitting or sit when all others are standing. This is the general rule: A man should not deviate from the custom of his companions or from society.13(13) Cf. DEZ V 5, p. 581. This paragraph is omitted here in H.

A guest should not say to his host, ‘Serve me that I may eat’, but [must wait] until he is invited to eat. If they poured out a goblet [of wine] for him he must drink it with pauses.1(1) Not in one draught. Cf. above, p. 554. How many pauses should he make? In the case of warm [beverages] three and with cold four. R. Judah said: This applies only to goblets of Galilee,2(2) Which were small. but with goblets used in Judah3(3) Which were large. he drinks with as many pauses as he likes.4(4) Without appearing haughty.

A man should not say to his fellow, ‘Come and eat [with me in return] for the food you gave me’, because this is a kind of usury.5(5) He may give him a more elaborate meal than he had eaten at the other’s house. In Jerusalem, however, they used to exchange invitations one with another.6(6) So GRA. They did not take the question of usury into consideration.

A man should not send to his fellow a barrel of wine and put oil at its mouth,7(7) Leading him to believe that the whole barrel contained oil. because this may lead to fatal consequences. It once happened that a man arranged a banquet in honour of his son; when his guests arrived and sat down at the table, he went to get the oil.8(8) So GRA and H. V reads ‘wine’, with a similar change in the next sentence. When he discovered that the barrel was full of wine he strangled himself and died.9(9) From shame, since he had nothing else prepared to set before his guests. Hence the Sages said: A man should not send to his fellow a barrel of wine and put oil at its mouth, because it may lead to fatal consequences.

A man should not say to his fellow, ‘Take oil’ from an empty jar,10(10) When he knows that the man will not do so. because the latter would be grateful to him without cause.11(11) He gains the gratitude of the man through something which he had no intention of doing. This is the reason in all the cases mentioned. A man should not urge his fellow to dine with him knowing that he will not do so; and he should not offer him many gifts when he knows that he will not accept them.

A man should not pass off new wine for old12(12) So GRA. V reverses the adjectives. H omits this sentence. when giving his friend a drink because that is a kind of robbery. If he was giving drink to ass-drivers, he may not say to them, ‘Take away this man’s cup and pass it to someone else’ because this is a kind of robbery.13(13) The suggestion is that he had had his drink when he had not.

If a man was standing by sellers of produce in a market-place, he may not say to them, ‘What is the price of this article?’ when he has no intention of buying it,14(14) To pretend interest in a purchase when he has no money is deception; cf. B.M. 58b (Sonc. ed., p. 347). because he encourages the mind15(15) This, too, is deception. The translation is according to H and NY. V reads ‘mistake’. of the seller [that he will sell it].

A man should not break bread over a dish,1(1) Lest crumbs fall into it and fastidious persons would not eat from the dish. wipe the plate with a piece of bread, or gather the crumbs and leave them on the table, because such action is objectionable to men.2(2) Following the text of GRA; also in the next sentence. One should not wipe the plate with a piece of bread and leave it on the table, because such action is objectionable to men. A man should not bite off a piece of bread and return it to the plate; similarly he should not bite off a piece of bread and give it to his fellow, because not all tastes are alike. He should also not drink from a cup and hand it to his fellow because of danger to life.3(3) The man may be fastidious and yet be forced to drink from it. It is permitted only after he had poured out some water from the cup to cleanse the rim; cf. Tamid 27b (Sonc. ed., p. 9). Once R. ‘Aḳiba was staying at the inn of a certain man who handed him a goblet of wine from which he had already drunk. R. ‘Aḳiba said to him, ‘Take and drink it’. [The host] again handed him another goblet of wine from which he had previously drunk, and R. ‘Aḳiba said to him, ‘Take and drink it’. Ben ‘Azzai said to him, ‘How long will you give [R. ‘Aḳiba] goblets of wine which had previously been tasted!’

It is also related of R. ‘Aḳiba that he was staying at the inn of a certain man [57b] who took a piece of bread and used it to support his plate.4(4) Displaying disrespect for food. R. ‘Aḳiba snatched [the bread] and ate it. [The innkeeper] said to him, ‘Master, have you no bread to eat other than that on which I rested the plate?’ He replied, ‘I imagined that you would be scalded with tepid water;5(5) i.e. I gave you a plain hint that this must not be done. but now6(6) Because of the question. [I see] that you are not scalded even with hot water’. A man should not drink his goblet and place it upon the table; but he should retain it until the waiter comes and then hand it to him.7(7) He may stain the tablecloth.

Rabbi [Judah the Prince] said the following five things [concerning bread]: we may not place raw meat on bread,8(8) So as not to spoil it; this is the reason in all the cases mentioned. we may not pass a cup [full of wine] or a plate [of soup] over bread, we may not throw bread, we may not rest a dish on bread and we may not sit on articles of food because it would crush them.9(9) It is disrespectful even if he does not make it repugnant. H reverses the order of the paragraphs. A guest may not take his portion and give it to the attendant, lest something untoward happen to [the rest of] the meal;10(10) And the guest will have had nothing to eat. but he should take [his portion], keep it in front of him and later hand it to the attendant. Guests may not give anything [from what is set before them] to the host’s son or to his servant or deputy unless they have received the host’s permission to do so. It once happened that in a time of scarcity a man invited three guests to his house and only had three eggs11(11) Some read ‘food of the size of three eggs’. which he set before them. When the host’s child entered and stood before them, one of the guests took his portion and gave it to him; the second guest did the same and so did the third. When the father came in and saw him with one egg in his mouth and holding two in his hands, he picked him up to his full height and flung him to the ground so that he died. When the mother saw her child dead she got up from [her seat] upon the roof12(12) The text in Ḥul. 94b (Sonc. ed., p. 529) states that she went up to the roof. and threw herself down and died. On seeing this, the father also stood on the roof and threw himself down and died. R. Eliezer b. Jacob said: Because of this three souls perished.

On entering a bath-house one should say, ‘May it be Thy will, O Lord my God, that Thou cause me to enter in peace and depart in peace, and that Thou cause me to return [to my house] in peace, and deliver me from this heat and its like in the future’.1(1) Cf. Ber. 60a (Sonc. ed., p. 376). How should he conduct himself2(2) i.e. in what order should he undress himself. before entering? He removes his shoes, then his hat, then his cloak, then his girdle, then his shirt and finally his underwear. When he finished washing and left [the bath] and is handed a towel, he should dry his head and then the rest of his body. When he is given the oil3(3) This is a necessary part of one’s toilet in hot countries. he should oil his head4(4) Because it is ‘the king of all the limbs’, Shab. 61a (Sonc. ed., p. 286). and then the rest of his body. He then puts on his underwear and his shirt, binds his girdle, dons his cloak, [puts his hat on] and finally his shoes. [If he has his son with him or his servant, they put on the shoes for him.]5(5) To spare him the fatigue. The words within brackets are inserted by GRA and H. He puts on the right [shoe] first and then the left, and when he removes them he takes the left off first and then the right.6(6) The right half of the body being stronger, more honour must be shown to it. Removing the left first is likewise a mark of honour to the right because the right shoe remains longer on the foot. It is the same in connection with the tefillin: he puts on that of the hand first and then that of the head,7(7) Cf. Deut. 6, 8, where the hand is mentioned first. and when he removes them he first takes off that of the head and then of the hand.8(8) Cf. Men. 36a (Sonc. ed., p. 224).

Who enters a bath-house should not knead9(9) i.e. massage strongly. or scrape10(10) With a strigil to invigorate the circulation. Cf. Shab. 147a (Sonc. ed., p. 747) where this is forbidden only on the Sabbath. Perhaps here it is only forbidden in the presence of many but not in the inner room where few people congregate (so NY). Another reading is ‘or have his limbs broken’, by a very vigorous massage. or urinate on the marble floor.11(11) In the presence of others, but he must retire to a corner. It once happened that they begged Rabban Gamaliel, who was weak, to urinate on the marble floor but he refused.12(12) [The translation is conjectural and suggested by the context. As it stands the text is unintelligible, but shemen, ‘oil’, seems to indicate a corruption of mashtin, ‘to urinate’.] Rabban Simeon b. Gamaliel said: He who urinates on the marble floor is the companion of an ass, and he who eats in the street is like a dog; some say that he is unfit to give evidence.13(13) Lack of self-respect may lead to one testifying falsely. Cf. Ḳid. 40b (Sonc. ed., p. 203). In the case of a privy he who is inside must give way14(14) i.e. hurry himself. to him who enters;15(15) Because to hold oneself back endangers health. but in the case of a bath-house he who is about to enter must give way16(16) i.e. wait. to him who is inside.17(17) He must wash himself completely with hot and then cold water before leaving the bath-house. Cf. DEZ VIII, p. 588. One may not bring into the bath-house oil in a glass vessel because of danger.18(18) In case the glass breaks. One may not spit in a bath-house because of danger.19(19) Someone may slip over it. One may not spit anywhere in the presence of others.

One may cite the rules appertaining to a privy in a privy and the rules appertaining to a bath-house in a bath-house.20(20) Cf. ‘A.Z. 44b (Sonc. ed., p. 221), ‘One may not discuss questions relating to Torah in a bath’. One should not extend a greeting21(21) lit. ‘inquire [after one’s peace] and reply’. in a place where people are undressed22(22) Cf. Shab. 10a (Sonc. ed., p. 36) where ‘peace’ is said to be one of God’s names. but only in a place where the majority present are dressed.23(23) So GRA. i.e. not in the inner chamber of the bath-house but in the outer chamber. If most of the persons present are dressed it is as though they are all dressed; if the majority are undressed it is as though they are all undressed. A man may not give greeting to his fellow in the bath-house on account of danger, and if one does greet him he should say, ‘It is a bath-house!’ Others say that he may return the greeting and it does not matter.

A man should not let his feet [dangle] in a bath-tub while he lies stretched out [naked], because it is immodest. A man should not say to his fellow in a bath-house, ‘Rub me in well with your hand’, and he who says so will not depart from there unscathed. R. Judah said: This only applies when there is little water,24(24) When the rubbing may arouse unclean thoughts. but when there is plenty of water it is all right. It is discreditable for a man to read [the Shema‘] twice25(25) Cf. Ber. 33b (Sonc. ed., p. 210, n. 7) where this applies only where he says each word of the Shema‘ twice. If he repeats the whole sentence he is to be silenced, because it may appear as if he addresses himself to two Powers, similar to the dualism of the Persians, a God of light and a God of darkness. NY suggests a reading ‘to wash himself twice’. or to immerse [in a ritual bath] twice.26(26) Because people may suspect that he associates too much with women, a ritual bath being required after a seminal emission.

If a man covers himself in his cloak and stays in the room where they sweat he is as if he robbed the public.27(27) He prevents another from using the bath. He who washes himself in cold water and then sluices himself with lukewarm water is as if he robbed the public.28(28) To wash oneself first in hot and then in cold water is beneficial to the body; to use up hot water after having already washed with cold is waste of water. And if one did rob the public what should he do?29(29) To make redress. He should go and dig wells, ditches and grottoes, or repair highways and streets,30(30) And so provide water for the general public among whom the aggrieved persons are to be found. and then he will be forgiven.

If one starts out on a journey alone before cock-crow his blood is upon his head.1(1) He courts danger. Cf. Yoma 21a (Sonc. ed., pp. 90f.). Pes. 2a (Sonc. ed., pp. 1f.) states, ‘A man should always enter a town by day and set out by day’. R. Josiah said: [He should wait] until [the cock] crowed at least twice.2(2) Or, until he has heard at least two crow. What kind of cock? The average type,3(3) That crows neither too early nor too late. as it is stated, Who hath put wisdom in the inward parts? or who hath given understanding to the coc?4(4) Job 38, 36. E.V. the mind.

If [immediately] on returning from a journey a man enters a bath-house, undergoes cupping, has marital intercourse and sleeps on the floor, his blood is upon his head.5(5) Following the text of GRA in agreement with Giṭ. 70a (Sonc. ed., p. 334). He will soon die because he had already been exhausted by his journey.

If one kills a louse upon his bed,6(6) Perhaps what is intended is that he should remove it from the bed because killing it there is unhygienic. or stands naked in front of a candle-light7(7) It is said to cause epilepsy; Pes. 112b (Sonc. ed., p. 579). or in the moonlight, his blood is upon his head.

[He who eats peeled garlic, a peeled egg or a peeled onion which were kept overnight] and he who drinks diluted liquids or uncovered water which were kept overnight, his blood is upon his head.8(8) So GRA. H omits the clause within brackets. Cf. Nid. 17a (Sonc. ed., p. 112).

[One may not sit at his table9(9) To eat. under an olive-tree on account of danger.10(10) So GRA. H omits the clause within brackets. The branches become weighted with olives and one may fall upon him.] He who drinks water from brooks, rivers or pools [direct] with his mouth or by [drawing the water] with one hand,11(11) Drawing the water with one hand and drinking it has to be done so rapidly that he has no time to examine it. his blood is upon his head because leeches are there.12(12) And there is the danger of his swallowing a leech; cf. ‘A.Z. 12b (Sonc. ed., p. 63).
If a man observes a fast after letting blood, his blood is upon his head.

They who write scrolls [of the Torah], tefillin and mezuzoth, they, their traders and traders’ traders13(13) i.e. all who trade in them directly or indirectly. will never see a sign of blessing [from their earnings].14(14) Cf. Pes. 50b (Sonc. ed., p. 246).
[They who deal in ritually unclean food and forbidden fat will never see a sign of blessing.]15(15) This paragraph is inserted by H.
He who trades in canes and jars will never see a sign of blessing.16(16) Their bulk is large and so the evil eye has power over them; Pes. loc. cit. (Sonc. ed., p. 245).

They who cut down [beautiful] trees,17(17) To sell for timber and thereby evokes astonishment. breeders of small cattle,18(18) Sheep, goats, etc. and they who trade on market-stands19(19) Market traders are exposed to the public gaze and so to the evil eye. Tosiftha Bek. II reads instead ‘shemiṭṭah’, the Sabbatical year when trading with its produce is forbidden. will never see a sign of blessing.
Anyone who sells his scroll [of the Torah] though he does not require it, or sells his daughter [to be a handmaid] though he has no food, will never see a blessing [from that money].

One who does work on the Ninth of Ab will never see a sign of blessing [in the work he does on that day].20(20) Added by GRA. Cf. Ta‘an. 30b (Sonc. ed., p. 161). R. ‘Aḳiba said: Scholars should abstain from work [on that day].21(21) Even in places where it is customary for people to work. It is the anniversary of the destruction of both Temples.

R. Isaac said: Slanderers are like shedders of blood, as it is stated, Thou shalt not go up and down as a talebearer among thy people; neither shalt thou stand idly by the blood of thy neighbour.22(22) Lev. 19, 16. R. Eliezer said: He who hates his fellow belongs to the shedders of blood, as it is stated, If any man hate his neighbour, and lie in wait for him, and rise up against him, and smite him, etc.23(23) Deut. 19, 11. Ben ‘Azzai said: He who hates his wife belongs to the shedders of blood, as it is stated, And if he lay wanton charges against her,24(24) ibid. XXII, 14. with the consequence that he hires [false] witnesses and has her hastily brought to the place of stoning.25(25) ibid. 21. R. Jose said: He who calculates the end26(26) i.e. the advent of the Messiah. has no portion in the World to Come.27(27) Because people will say that, since the predetermined time has arrived and the Messiah has not come, he will never come. Cf. Sanh. 97b (Sonc. ed., p. 659). He who hates Sages and their disciples, a false prophet and he who spreads calumny have no portion in the World to Come.

R. Meir said: Whoever has a House of Study in his town and does not frequent it forfeits his life,28(28) Ber. 8a (Sonc. ed., p. 39) reads ‘Synagogue’, a dictum of Resh Laḳish. as it is stated, Thus saith the Lord: What unrighteousness have your fathers found in Me that they are gone far from Me?29(29) Jer 2, 5. The proof-text is added by GRA. How much more so [if he does not attend] an Academy which contains thousands and myriads of Biblical precepts! R. Meir said: Anyone who has a scholar near him and does not wait upon him [as a disciple] forfeits his life, as it is stated, Because he hath despised the word of the Lord.30(30) Num. 15, 31.

Anyone who goes into the street with his shoes unlaced is haughty of spirit. [He who walks] with his sanṭer31(31) A kind of cloak. hanging side-ways,32(32) Over his shoulder. or his cap turned backwards, or [sits] crosslegged, or holds in his hand the straps of the tefillin and puts them back while walking in the street belongs to the haughty of spirit. Every man in whom there is haughtiness of spirit is as though he worships idols,33(33) So GRA. as it states, Thou shalt not bring an abomination into thine house,34(34) Deut. 7, 26, the reference being to an idolatrous image. and it states elsewhere, Every one that is proud in heart is an abomination to the Lord:35(35) Prov. 16, 5. the word abomination is written in the one connection and also in the other—as the abomination mentioned in the one refers to idolatry so the abomination mentioned in the other refers to idolatry.

On going to bed one says, ‘Blessed … Who causeth [58a] the bands of sleep to fall upon my eyes’,36(36) So GRA. V has ‘upon men’. Cf. P.B., p. 293. and on waking he says, ‘O my God, the soul which Thou hast given me is pure’.37(37) P.B., p. 5. On turning on his side from his sleep he says, ‘Blessed … Who looseneth the bound’.38(38) P.B., p. 6. So GRA. V and H read: ‘Who openest the eyes of the blind’.

On entering a privy one should say, ‘Be honoured, ye honoured and holy beings who minister to the Most High! Give glory to our God and stay where you are. Help me, guard me, support me and wait for me until I enter and come out, for this is the way of human beings’.39(39) Addressing the angels who are believed to accompany one to the privy, which was regarded as a haunt of evil spirits. On leaving a privy one says, ‘Blessed is He Who has formed man in wisdom’.40(40) P.B., p. 4. When he has washed his face he says, ‘Blessed … Who removest the bands of sleep from my eyes and slumber from my eyelids’.41(41) ibid. p. 6 bot.

When he is clothed and goes out into the street he should say,<sup><xref rid="fn1450">42</xref></sup> ‘May it be Thy will, O Lord my God, that Thou conduct me in peace and uphold me in peace; and let me obtain grace, favour and mercy in Thine eyes and in the eyes of all who behold me; bestow lovingkindnesses upon me, and cause me to return to my house in peace. Deliver me from the hand of every enemy and ambush by the way and from an evil tongue. Let me not become accustomed to sin, transgression or iniquity, and let me not err in a matter of <italic>halakah</italic> or in any matter whatsoever. Deliver me from all kinds of harm and from all manner of afflictions which break forth and come upon the world that they do not injure me by day or by night. Blessed is He Who bestoweth lovingkindnesses upon His people Israel’.<sup><xref rid="fn1451">43</xref></sup>
May it be the will of the Holy One, blessed be He, that He cause us to behold the rejoicing and comfort of Jerusalem, Amen.
